data.title: 50 Best Drinking Songs and Songs About Drinking, By Time Out Editors
data.meta_description: Raise a glass to the best drinking songs of all time! These songs about drinking pair nicely with wine, beer and whisky.
data.text:
If youâ€™re anything like us, most often when youâ€™re dancing, youâ€™re also drinking. So hey, itâ€™s no surprise that a large number of tunes out there are about doing just that â€“ booze!

And weâ€™ve rounded up the best of the boozy best, right here, from Rihanna to Chumbawumba (you know the one we mean). So fill up that cup and wack on this playlist: itâ€™s time to dance. Here are the best songs about drinking to wet the whistle.

RECOMMENDED:

ğŸ‰ The best party songs ğŸ¤ The best karaoke songs

ğŸ•º The best pop songs of all time

ğŸ˜ƒ The best happy songs

ğŸ† The best sexy songs

Written by Michael Chen, Brent DiCrescenzo, Sophie Harris, Oliver Keens, Andy Kryza, Hank Shteamer, Kate Wertheimer, Zach Long, Matthew Singer, Leonie Cooper and Camille Bavera.

1. â€˜Gin & Juiceâ€™ by Snoop Dogg

This was the first rap song to provide high-school parties with a cocktail recipe right in the title. Well, juice can be expensive. But â€˜Gin & Gatoradeâ€™ just doesnâ€™t have the same mellifluousness. On a side note, whenâ€™s the last time you heard someone refer to weed as â€˜indoâ€™? 1994?

2. â€˜Make It Another Old-Fashioned, Pleaseâ€™, Julie London

With a voice as smooth as the whiskey she's singing about, vintage torch singer Julie London makes an Old Fashioned the only cocktail worth ordering with her silky take on this Cole Porter classic. â€˜Make it for one who's due to join the disillusion crew/Make it for one of love's new refugees,â€™ she croons â€“ though she doesnâ€™t sound too upset about her lovelorn situation. Thatâ€™s the power of a stiff drink, I suppose.

Leonie Cooper

Food and Drink Editor, Time Out London

Advertising

3. â€˜Streams of Whiskeyâ€™ by The Pogues

In one of the folk-punk outfits peppiest (or at least whistle-iest) hits, Pogues frontman Shane MacGowan spins a yarn about a dream he had (presumably not while sober) of walking hand in hand with Irish poet Brendan Behan and learning of an afterlife where the brown stuff flows in rivers. (Thereâ€™s also talk of a 15-beer bender, because The Pouges are gonna Pogues). Forced to choose one Pogues song â€” this list could have been nothing but Pogues songs â€” itâ€™s â€˜Streams of Whiskeyâ€™ by a drinkerâ€™s nose.

4. â€˜Doses and Mimosasâ€™ by Cherub

â€˜Doses and Mimosasâ€™ is one of those silly, catchy tunes that sort of sounds like it should be in a car advert, but you love it anyway. In true 2013 fashion, the â€˜Cherubâ€™ duo uploaded this track to YouTube only to become a viral sensation in just one week, garnering one and a half million views and a deal with Columbia records. May it forever live on as a reminder of, well, drinking mostly.

Camille Bavera

Contributor, Time Out London

Advertising

5. â€˜Lilac Wineâ€™ by Nina Simone

Originally penned in 1950 for a theater revue, â€˜Lilac Wineâ€™ has been covered by such greats as Eartha Kitt, Jeff Buckley and, er, Miley Cyrus. But only the High Priestess of Soul is able to give this moody ode to infatuation the drama and chill its lyrics and melody beg for. In her 1966 interpretation, her voice prowls around the songâ€™s deliciously dark lyrics like a cat, and for the listener, intoxication is inevitable.

6. â€˜Brass Monkeyâ€™ by Beastie Boys

Itâ€™s an obvious observation, but this song came out before the Internet. Which means that I â€“ like tens of thousands of 12-year-olds in 1986, I would imagine â€“ was unable to immediately figure out what the hell the B Boys were whine-shouting about. Iâ€™ll admit it: I thought the rap was about a monkey. Then, in high school, I learned from friends that a Brass Monkey was a sort of gutter mimosa â€“ malt liquor and O.J. Gross. Then, in college, thanks to the World Wide Web, I discovered the source of that funk-skronk horn: Wild Sugarâ€™s deep-disco cut, â€˜Bring It Here.â€™ Rad. And they say friends are better than the Internet.

Advertising

7. â€˜Whiskey Riverâ€™ by Willie Nelson

Some consideration was given to â€˜I Gotta Get Drunk,â€™ a 1970 Willie tune covered wonderfully by Phosphorescent in 2009. But that was the short-haired, clean-shaven Willie. On principle, we went with this classic off of Shotgun Willie, from the dawn of his stoner-cowboy era. Even though it was written by Johnny Bush, the song belongs to Willie, as essential to him as long braids and a bandanna.

8. â€˜Too Drunk to Fuckâ€™ by Dead Kennedys

Hey, itâ€™s happened to the best of us. This 1981 surf-rock-heavy single was the fourth from the California punkers, who paint an exaggerated party picture mostly to offend music-industry prudes. Although the song reached No. 36 on the U.K. singles chart, it was often banned or censored, leading the Kennedys to supply a sticker for record shops reading â€˜Caution: You are the victim of yet another stodgy retailer afraid to warp your mind by revealing the title of this record, so peel slowly and seeâ€¦â€™ Nice touch, Biafra.

Advertising

9. â€˜Sippinâ€™ on Some Syrupâ€™ by Three 6 Mafia

Cough medicine plus Sprite, plus Jolly Ranchers. Holy shit, people drink that? Sprite? Look, when youâ€™re broke, you have to get creative with your addictions. Anything can become a habit. As Pimp C proclaimed in this song in 2000: â€˜We eat so many shrimp, Iâ€™ve got iodine poisoning.â€™ So how did this Memphis hip-hop troupe go on to win an Oscar in 2006, for â€˜It's Hard Out Here for a Pimpâ€™? Even pharmacists would have a hard time finding rhymes for promethazine and hydrocodone.

10. â€˜Alabama Song (Whisky Bar)â€™ by the Doors

Penned by Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weill for the incendiary 1930 opera Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny, this song was originally performed by a chorus of prostitutes. This more famous cover was recorded by the Doors in 1966 with a carnivalesque sound that perfectly illustrates what it's like to be smashed and along for the ride (which Jim Morrison very likely was).

11. â€˜Friends in Low Placesâ€™ by Garth Brooks

You canâ€™t help but sing along with the common people at the local watering hole when the jukebox starts playing Garth Brooksâ€™s 1990 ode to drinking the blues away. Youâ€™ll suddenly find yourself line dancing with folks youâ€™ve never met and seeing if your vocal register can go to those low places in the songâ€™s signature chorus. And, of course, there will be plenty of whiskey and beer flowing. Fun fact: In the perfect marriage of song to hapless sports team, the Kansas City Royals (two winning seasons in the last 19 years) adopted â€˜Friends in Low Placesâ€™ as their sixth-inning sing-along anthem. It serves as a constant reminder to beleaguered fans that misery loves companyâ€¦and booze.

Michael Chen

12. â€˜Tubthumpingâ€™ by Chumbawumba

Anyone who knew of the British anarcho-punk band in their indie days mustâ€™ve been completely baffled when the group signed to a major in the mid-â€™90s and hit it big with this exuberant ode to getting drunk, getting knocked down and getting back up again. It persists as a source of inspiration for suburban normies, but thatâ€™s sort of the point - the band has described the song as being about â€˜the resilience of ordinary peopleâ€™. It also catalogs their curious drinking habits. A whiskey drink, a vodka drink, a lager drink and a cider drink? Maybe stop mixing your alcohol and you wonâ€™t fall down so much.

Matthew Singer

Film writer and editor

Advertising

13. â€˜Here Comes a Regularâ€™ and â€˜Beer for Breakfastâ€™ (tie) by the Replacements

From what Iâ€™ve heard and seen on YouTube of their early concerts, the Mats made all their songs drinking songs. The gloriously shambolic punk stuff raged like an adolescent who's seen a specter of his older self just ahead, slumped at a local bar and stamped with a gas-station name tag. Conversely, young Paul Westerbergâ€™s ballads carried the sadness of a middle-aged nobody yearning for his salad days. Somehow, the Minnesotans shifted between these two gears without blowing the clutch, as heard in these respective cuts from 1985 and â€™87.

14. â€˜Thereâ€™s a Tear in My Beerâ€™ by Hank Williams Sr.

Though only one carried the title outright, all of Williamsâ€™s songs were â€˜Long Gone Lonesome Bluesâ€™ at heart. The Alabama-born legend was tough as an old strip of donkey jerky, yet many of his songs revolved around crying. It made him more of a man â€“ a man with a leather liver. â€˜These last nine beers,â€™ he sings in that high hillbilly whine on this Nashville session, have only convinced him: â€˜Iâ€™m gonna keep drinkinâ€™ until I'm petrified.â€™ A couple years later, in 1953, they pulled his body out of a Caddy littered with beer cans and lyric sheets.

Advertising

15. â€˜Drunken Lullabiesâ€™ by Flogging Molly

When youâ€™re a few drinks in, thereâ€™s something about driving rhythms and violin melodies that makes you want to sing along at the top of your lungs. Celtic punks Flogging Molly understand this phenomenon well, so it stands to reason that the title track of their 2002 record is a song about the songs you belt out after a few shots of whiskey.

16. â€˜Why Donâ€™t We Get Drunkâ€™ by Jimmy Buffet

Seems old Jimmy stopped looking for that shaker of salt, shrugged and switched his focus to hooking up with another drunkard at the bar. On a water bed, no less. Because of course Jimmy Buffet â€“ in his pre-Margaritaville country phase of the early â€˜70s â€“ does gross things on a water bed.

Advertising

17. â€˜Shotsâ€™ by LMFAO featuring Lil Jon

We hate this song as much as you do. Of course we do. But the entire belly-shot community would beg to differ. And answer us this: Has any piece of music better simulated the jackhammering headache of a Russian-grade hangover?

18. â€˜Cheap Beerâ€™ by FIDLAR

â€˜Beerâ€™s always better with a bag around it,â€™ the skater punks of FIDLAR (an acronym for Fuck It, Dawg, Lifeâ€™s a Risk â€“ really) proclaim over polluted waves of crust-surf guitar in this 2013 burner. â€˜I! Drink! Cheap! Beer! So! What! Fuck! You!â€™ shouts the chorus. Gotta respect a band whose entire raison dâ€™Ãªtre is to score shitty brews via tour riders. Would you really rather listen to Animal Collective, hippie?

Advertising

19. â€˜Sunday Morninâ€™ Cominâ€™ Downâ€™ by Kris Kristofferson

Most of the songs on this list celebrate nights of debauchery, but only Kris Kristofferson thought to pour one out for the blurry morning after. The country troubadourâ€™s ode to morning beers, sleepy city sidewalks, fried-chicken envy and pounding headaches is one of the loveliest country tunes ever written (Johnny Cash does a stellar take): Far from a Hangover-style (or Katy Perryâ€™s â€˜Last Friday Nightâ€™) recap of a rowdy night, Kristoffersonâ€™s song is a quiet, reflective number that pops with descriptive poetry and introspection. Now somebody makes this manâ€™s wish come true and get him stoned.

20. â€˜Pass the Courvoisier, Part IIâ€™ by Busta Rhymes

Likely in constant rotation on Ladies Man Leon Phelpsâ€™ playlist, this megahit for Busta came at the height of hip hopâ€™s obsession with luxury items, but donâ€™t worry, itâ€™s just as smooth if youâ€™re drinking Black Velvet while listening. Rhymesâ€™s signature rat-a-tat growl pairs nicely with the slick Neptunes beat, with Diddy and Pharrell even showing up to affirm that yes, they too would enjoy a glass of Courvasier.

41. â€˜Cheers (Drink to That)â€™ by Rihanna

A toast to our interns, who chided us for overlooking this my-first-reggaetÃ³n chillaxer from 2010. â€˜Don't let the bastards get you down,â€™ RiRi sings in her patois. Basic Rihanna rule: The more Caribbean she sounds, the better. Jameson Irish whiskey gets plugged heavily over a sample of Avril Lavigne, which reeks of product placement (there's a shout-out to Ray-Bans, too, official hangover concealer of Rihanna), but at least it's not Malibu.

42. â€˜Warm Beer and Cold Womenâ€™ by Tom Waits

â€¦makes the rankings on title alone. But this creaky weeper from 1975's Nighthawks at the Diner manages to rhyme vermouth with Naugahyde booth, too. Admit it: Young-barfly Tom Waits totally destroys old-man-in-a-rusty-shed-with-a-mule Tom Waits.

Advertising

43. â€˜Drunk Girlsâ€™ by LCD Soundsystem

Is â€˜Drunk Girlsâ€™ LCD Soundsystemâ€™s finest hour? No, of course not. But does it feel like a night of reckless boozing in New York City? Absolutely. James Murphy himself has described the 2010 single as â€˜dumb.â€™ But, he added, â€˜I like dumb, short stuff.â€™ More reasons to dig â€˜Drunk Girlsâ€™? The wince-inducing video, codirected by Spike Jonze, shows Murphy and the LCD crew being manhandled by malevolent pandas. Dumb â€˜nâ€™ short 4 evah.

44. â€˜One Mint Julepâ€™ by Louis Prima

Fleeting happiness in the haze of a drunken hour: Many songs have trod this path, but in the words of this jazz-pop standard, â€˜One mint julep / Was the start of it all.â€™ Originally a hit for â€™50s doo-wop group the Clovers on Atlantic Records, the tune tells of stealing an intoxicated kiss from a woman after one sweet, minty cocktail, only to get hitched (at her father's demand) and end up confused, hungover and the father of six kids. Quite the tipple. Though Ray Charles's 1961 instrumental cover made it a hit, Louis Prima's unmistakably comic tone gives his version the edge.

Advertising

45. â€˜Shot For Meâ€™ by Drake

If this booze-soaked R&B ode to former flames sounds like something that the Weeknd should be singing, that's just because Abel Tesfaye actually wrote it. Released back when Drake was extremely in his feelings and fancied himself a singer (as well as a rapper), â€˜Shot For Meâ€™ finds the Canadian star spitefully reminding his exes to remember just how great he was when they knock back a glass of Canadian Club, or whatever folks shoot in Toronto.

46. â€˜Drunk in Loveâ€™ by BeyoncÃ©

Yes, ostensibly itâ€™s a love song, but câ€™mon, BeyoncÃ© was likely deep in her cups last year when she blurted the non sequitur hashtag â€˜Surfbordt!â€™ Ditto for Jay-Z, who could not have been sober when he wrote, â€˜Your breastesses is my breakfast.â€™ I think he stole that from Bukowski?

Advertising

47. â€˜Cigarettes, Whuskey, and Wild, Wild Womenâ€™ by Sons of Pioneers

A sing-songy ode to the insanity-inducing allure of tobacco, brown liquor and the fairer sex, this old-timey barn-burner has been covered a billion or so times, with Buck Owens, Jim Croce and Ron Wood all offering up solid versions. The best, though? Itâ€™s the version performed by Peter Sellers and a cadre of felt hillbillies in covered-wagon times during his hosting stint on The Muppet Show. And no, we didnâ€™t just make that up because weâ€™ve been drinking â€˜whuskeyâ€™ while writing.

48. â€˜Whiskey Girlâ€™ by Gillian Welch

There are drinking songs to carouse to, and there are drinking songs to listen to at 4am while you pour out another whiskey and your mind turns over what couldâ€™ve been, or where you could get cigarettes at this hour. Taken from Gillian Welchâ€™s exquisite, bleak 1998 album, Hell Among the Yearlings, â€˜Whiskey Girlâ€™ falls into the latter category â€“ and how.

Advertising

49. â€˜Bubbles in my Beerâ€™ by Bob Wills

Eventually covered by the likes of Willie Nelson and George Jones, this 1947 Western swing standard may well have started the sub-genre of woeful country songs about drinking away your sorrows. Itâ€™s bit antiquated and a little depressing, but itâ€™s one of the jauntiest tunes about self-absorbed contemplation youâ€™ll ever hear.

50. â€˜You and Me and the Bottle Make Threeâ€™ by Big Bad Voodoo Daddy

Back in the â€˜90s, the universe declared that what America needed was a big-band swing revival, and BBVD led the charge with this boozy anthem that ensured a whole subculture would suffer concussions due to ill-advised swing dancing after several drinks. (Whether it also resulted in a spike in dancefloor-based concussions is unknown.) The song got huge via the film Swingers... then disappeared from the collective consciousness along with the Cherry â€™ Daddies. But when it resurfaces, it's a stealth hit for anyone who ever used â€˜that's so moneyâ€™ in casual conversation.
